thread.title: Sunday morning quarterback: Stars and stats from the BYU win over East Carolina
thread.title_full: Sunday morning quarterback: Stars and stats from the BYU win over East Carolina | Deseret News

author: Jay Yeomans
title: Sunday morning quarterback: Stars and stats from the BYU win over East Carolina
text:
A look at how the Cougars performed in their win over the Pirates, and a what you need to know about the Cincinnati Bearcats.
Scoreboard BYU EAST CAROLINA 0 0 Full box score/Player stats Upcoming Games BYU Football BYU   Cincinnati @ BYU Lavell Edwards Stadium, Provo Oct. 16, 6:00 p.m. 5  Days   2  Hrs   33  Mins   54  Secs More Coverage BYU report card: Tanner Mangum brings his A game to put away Pirates BYU defense makes plays when it needs to against explosive ECU offense Mangum looks like Bosco to lead BYU past East Carolina PROVO â€” The BYU Cougars answered the bell late in the fourth quarter as they managed to overcome a 17-point Pirates comeback to knock off East Carolina 45-38 at LaVell Edwards Stadium on Saturday night.
The return of quarterback Tanner Mangum sparked the Cougar offense for one final scoring drive to break the tie and give BYU a 4-2 record on the season.
Scoring recap 
The Pirates got on the board first when quarterback James Summers scored on a 34-yard run on a fourth-and-3. An Algernon Brown fumble gave East Carolina the ball with solid field position to set up the drive.
East Carolina stretched the lead to 14 when a Jonny Linehan punt was blocked by Trevian Hicks and recovered by Yiannis Bowden in the end zone.
BYU finally got on the scoreboard when Mangum connected with Brown for a 22-yard touchdown. One of the most important plays came when Mangum found Devon Blackmon for a 17-yard gain on third-and-18 to give the Cougars a manageable fourth-down attempt.
The Cougars tied the game when Brown scored on a 1-yard touchdown run. The drive was set up by a blocked punt from Bronson Kaufusi that was recovered by Trey Dye at the 1-yard line.
BYU took its first lead of the night when Mangum found Mitch Mathews for a 13-yard touchdown. The score was set up by a 7-yard run by Linehan on a fake punt to keep the drive alive.
The Cougars scored their fourth straight touchdown for the 28-14 lead when Mangum found Terenn Houk for the 9-yard touchdown. The big play on the drive came when Blackmon had a 39-yard catch on a pass from Mangum.
The Pirates closed the gap to 28-21 when Blake Kemp found Trevon Brown for the 1-yard touchdown with six seconds remaining in the first half. Bryce Williams made two nice plays on the possession with catches of 24 and 11 yards.
BYU answered on the opening drive of the second half when Algie Brown scored on a 53-yard run. He also had another big play on the drive when he gained 5 yards on a third-and-1.
The Cougars pushed the lead to 17 when Trevor Samson hit a field goal from 37 yards out. Mangum came up huge to extend the drive when he scrambled and gained 7 yards on a fourth-and-6.
The Pirates cut the deficit to 10 when Chris Hairston scored from 2 yards out. The touchdown run was set up by a 32-yard Kemp completion to Bryce Williams and a 36-yard catch by Hairston.
Kemp led East Carolina back to the end zone when he connected with Isaiah Jones for a 7-yard touchdown to cut the BYU lead to 38-35. A huge play on the drive came when Trevon Brown got free for a 35-yard catch on third-and-7.
The Pirates got the ball back when Bowden intercepted a Beau Hoge to set up a game-tying 34-yard field goal from Davis Plowman. A key play on the possession came when Jones caught a 22-yard pass from Kemp.
Algie Brown finished the scoring on the night as he gave the Cougars the 45-38 win with a 9-yard touchdown run with 19 seconds remaining. One of the most important plays came when Mangum connected with Houk for a 15-yard gain on third-and-10.
Three stars 
3. Devon Blackmon 
Blackmon had his most productive game as a Cougar. He finished with a team-high and personal-best nine receptions for a career-high 142 yards. His previous bests came against Boise State when he caught six passes for 105 yards.
2. Tanner Mangum 
Mangum made big plays with his arm and his legs for the Cougars. He completed 24 of 33 passes for 332 yards, including touchdowns of 22, 13 and 9 yards.
1. Algernon Brown 
Brown had is best game at BYU by far. He carried the ball 24 times for 134 yards, including touchdown runs of 1, 53 and 9 yards. He added two catches for 20 yards and another score.
Analyzing the stats 
The 134 rushing yards by Brown exceeded his rushing total for his first three games of the season. Entering the game, he had carried the ball 26 times for 118 yards. His four touchdowns are one more score than his entire BYU career coming into Saturday afternoon.
Mangum completed a career-high 72.7 percent of his passes. That is the best total by a BYU signal-caller since Taysom Hill completed 77.8 percent of his throws in the opening game of 2014.
Even though the Cougars gave up a season-high 38 points in the win, the defense came up with plenty of big plays. Sione Takitaki had 2.5 tackles for loss, two sacks and a fumble recovery while Fred Warner had a fumble recovery and an interception.
BYU gave up 518 yards to the East Carolina offense. That is the most yards against the Cougar defense all season. The 385 passing yards from the Pirates is also the most the Cougars have given up in 2015.
With the win, BYU improved to 3-0 at home to start the year. It is the first time that the Cougars have started out the home schedule with three straight wins since 2012.
Up next 
The Cincinnati Bearcats pay the Cougars a visit Friday night. The Bearcats come into the game with a record of 3-2 with wins over Alabama A&M, Miami (OH) and Miami (FL). Their losses have comes at the hands of a pair of undefeated teams in Temple and Memphis.
The Cincinnati offense is fifth in the nation averaging 587 yards per game, including 385.8 yards passing and 201.4 yards rushing. The Bearcats' 39 points a game is tied for 16th-best in the FBS.
Freshman signal-caller Hayden Moore has been taking the snaps of late after the injury to Gunner Kiel. Moore had completed 59.6 percent of his throws for 1,061 yards with seven touchdowns and five interceptions.
The offense really spreads the ball around in the passing game with five players totaling more than two hundred yards receiving and three with more than 300 yards. The key weapons in the passing game are Shaq Washington and Max Morrison. Washington leads the way with 34 receptions for 392 yards and two scores while Morrison has 24 catches for 351 yards and a pair of scores.
Tion Green and Hosey Williams lead the ground attack. Green has 76 carries for 383 yards and three touchdowns while Williams has carried the ball 67 times for 351 yards and a pair of scores.
Jay Yeomans is a courier by day and a freelance writer by night. He is the creator and lead writer of the website jmoneysports.com . Contact him at jmoney34@hotmail.com . Twitter: @jmoneysports
